Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Smart Radar Sensor for Pervasive Motion-Adaptive Health Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:The objective of this CAREER proposal is to resolve some of the significant problems currently limiting microwave biomedical radar in an innovative approach equipped with adaptive circuits and sensor fusion. A ?smart? portable biomedical radar sensor will be devised for pervasive motion-adaptive health care by monitoring the important physiological motion of human beings. The proposed approach is founded on a hybrid of radar and camera solutions, enabled by novel agile RF/analog circuits and demodulation algorithms. The hand-in-hand revolution of hardware and algorithms enables an adaptive radar architecture that can dynamically tune multiple operation points to combat clutter generated DC drift and the associated signal distortion. Fusion with a portable camera will ensure effective noise and interference removal, which would be otherwise impossible to do using multiple radars only. Furthermore, a CMOS smart-radar-on-chip solution will be conceived to demonstrate the feasibility of truly portable biomedical radar devices that could be as popular as an iPhone. The impact will be embodied as a revolution in human life style and quality. Software configurability will be a driving force in this effort to revolutionize the capability of radar systems to achieve being ?smart?. The proposed research bridges the fields of biomedical engineering, microwave engineering, embedded systems, and radar signal processing.
Broader Impact:The proposed smart radar sensor system will have broad impacts on health care solutions to benefit the long-term U.S. healthcare program. If successful, this research can be directly used for the monitoring and treatment of sleep apnea and sudden infant death syndrome. It can outperform other technologies in motion-adaptive tumor tracking during cancer radiotherapy in many anatomic sites. When configured as a nonlinear vibrometer, the radar will also advance approaches to monitoring rotating and reciprocating machinery in the transportation and manufacturing industries. This program will provide a thorough understanding of the capability and limitations of continuous wave radar sensors for short-range applications, which is not only valuable to the scientific community, but also beneficial to education in general. The studies involved in this research are at the crossroads of engineering and health care disciplines, and will enable unique educational opportunities that are often missing in traditional engineering curriculums. The program will provide the opportunity to strengthen electrical and computer skills of health care professionals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has solved some of the key problems for low-power miniature microwave biomedical radar to monitor physiological signs and track human beings without requiring any device on the body. Smart portable circuits and systems technologies have been devised for pervasive motion-adaptive health care by monitoring important physiological motions and the location of human beings. The developed technologies include a hybrid of radar and camera system for random body motion cancellation, a digital post-distortion technique for error correction, a hybrid frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW)-interferometry scheme with programmable low- intermediate frequency (IF) architecture for indoor precise positioning and versatile life activity monitoring, a multi-radar cooperative network, a radio frequency (RF) beamforming architecture without use of any phase shifter for a K-band portable FMCW radar, a K-band portable 3-D multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) radar aided by digital beamforming and nonuniformly spaced array, as well as frequency-shift keying methods for tracking and vital signs sensing. In these developed technologies, software configured agile RF/analog circuits and demodulation were a driving force that revolutionized the capability of radar systems to become ‘smart’. The team has carried out extensive experiments with different human subjects and physiological conditions, as instantaneous physiological dynamics are important indicators of human health condition and life quality.

 

During the six years of this project, three PhD students, two MS students, four undergraduate students, and two high school students received professional training on circuit design, system optimization, and advanced radar signal analysis. They gained experience of international collaboration with researchers from Spain, China, and Taiwan. The project results have been disseminated to general public through paper publications, conference presentations, and invited talks. The students have received multiple international recognitions such as best paper awards, design competition awards, and fellowship/scholarship from international technical professional organizations. All the PhD students have graduated and continued with a career in smart radar research, with two in industry and one in academia. Three undergraduate students have already entered graduate school.

 

The project had led to broader impacts to many areas. For example, such a non-contact, yet economical approach opened a new era without the need of expensive sleep labs to diagnose sleep apnea and sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Sleep apnea affects more than twelve million Americans and is associated with high blood pressure, arrhythmia, stroke and heart failure, and SIDS is the third leading cause of infant mortality. The developed technologies will also help seniors and people with disabilities by reading their gentle hand gestures or body languages, thus playing a key role in aging in place and home-based transitional care. By extending RF sensing with adaptive beamforming to continuously follow humans and track their activities, the research team has opened doors for lighting, heating, and air conditioning management, thus enabling smart services that contribute to energy efficiency and environmental conservation. The technology also finds vast internet of things (IoT) applications by wirelessly connecting humans, utilities, and smart devices together. Using smart radar sensors for time vocal folds vibration detection, the feasibility of auditory analysis with background rejection and directional discrimination was successfully demonstrated. Moreover, the team has shown that smart portable radar sensor could be a viable solution for wind turbine blade monitoring by detecting the distortion of blades even when the blades are rotating.

 

The research carried out in this project is transformative and bridges the fields of biomedical engineering, microwave engineering, embedded systems, and signal processing. Its impact will continue to be embodied as a revolution in human lifestyle and quality.
